history.content:
I'm a sophomore currently taking the semester off to intern in a SWE role. Below are some pros/cons I'd mention.

Pros:

Income: The income is really helpful. I can live fairly comfortably and save a decent amount to use in future semesters.

Stress: Taking some time away from Cal has been a really great de-stresser. I feel very rested and ready to kill it in the Fall!

Work Experience: Like any internship I've gotten a ton of professional experience. Even more than a summer internship (a semester is a month longer than a summer).

Cons:

Withdrawing: In order to do this you have to formally withdraw from Cal. It's not as big of a deal as it sounds, but there's a decent amount of paperwork you have to sort through to withdraw and be readmitted. Time it correctly to register for your Spring classes.

Housing: Depending on where you are interning, it can be difficult to find good housing for ~4 months. I've had some success with AirBnB. You could get an apartment but short term leases are expensive and you might have to find your own furniture.

Course Planning: I got thrown off a little bit in terms of my academic plans, specifically with courses taught only in Spring / Fall. Plan your future semesters carefully before you commit.

Social Life: Depending on where you intern, you probably won't see much of your friends from Cal, and there probably won't be other interns like there are in the summer. You also do not get long breaks to visit family as you would during a typical semester.

Overall, whether it's a good idea or not is going to depend a lot on your specific situation. For me, I'm really happy I did this! Feel free to reach out norell@berkeley.edu.

children.subject:
I went the route of extending my summer internship into a part-time internship during the school year. 

Similar pros and cons, except that it’s more stress during the school year (though if you balance your schedule well, it’s no more stressful than a regular semester). Also, you don’t have to worry about being readmitted/withdrawn. 

Definitely wouldn’t recommend it for everyone, but it’s an option.

If you are going to do an off-cycle internship I would advise you to do one in the spring instead of the summer. Recruiting for your next job will most likely happen during the Fall and it is going to be difficult to take days off to attend onsite interviews if you are working full time as an intern.

Hey, op here, do you know if your registration date when you came back was later than your peers? I'm a sophomore right now, so if I take fall 2019 off, but "reapply" for the next year and register for classes fall 2019, would I have a later registration date than other juniors during fall 2019?

Agreed with the student answer on all points. I took an entire year off and it was mainly due to personal circumstances as well as finances. The pros mentioned are all great - especially the stress part, it's a nice way to get out of the daily grind of classes, especially if you're feeling burned out, and actually apply what you've learned in a real-world setting.

That being said, to emphasize on some of the cons already mentioned:

- Withdrawing - this is indeed a bit of a hassle, and you have to make sure to be in constant contact with your advisers, go through the proper procedures, etc etc.

- Housing - this one is probably the biggest concern. I was able to sublet my place here in Berkeley during my gap year so I didn't have to search for a place when coming back and the move back in was comfortable, living with people who I already knew. I'm also local to the Bay Area so was able to commute from my home and didn't need to worry about finding a temporary place.

- Course Planning - again, a bit of a hassle as you have to redo your schedule, and this can be an even bigger concern if you're undeclared/trying to switch to a different major.

Overall, I loved my gap year and would wholeheartedly recommend it. It's long enough to gain worthwhile experience and a great way to spend your time away from Berkeley - gain work experience, get paid, and have fun!

when I did it I thought withdrawing was fairly easy, I just submitted a form in person over the summer and then did some stuff electronically to get readmitted.

I feel like I missed out on class experience and research opportunities but I did gain a lot of professional experience!

I interned away from home outta state in Seattle, and got a lil homesick at times but going to meetups and doing random things and meeting new people made the time away bearable. 

Also I totally forgot about recruiting so if you do a Fall internship, don't forget to prep for recruiting! also go to hackathons and stuff it's a lot of fun.

history.content:
I'm highly considering interning this fall due to various academic and personal reasons. The main reason I want to is finances, but I think it'll also be good to get as much industry experience as possible since I'm quite sure I want to go down the SWE route. I'm currently a sophomore and I think I'd like to try getting an internship this Fall 2019 (where I would have been a 1st semester junior).

I know most people intern during the summer since Berkeley doesn't have a co-op program, but if there are any of you who interned during Fall/Spring, could you maybe give some details about your experience in terms of pros/cons?

Was it overall worth it for you? Did it set you back academically/make your remaining semesters harder since you have to pack more classes? Do you think it made much of a difference in terms of getting more experience or do you think that nothing would have changed much (professionally) if you didn't have this internship?

I think I should have enough units to graduate in 3.5 years so I can still graduate at my anticipated date, but it'll make it so that I have to pack more classes into my schedule in a given semester. So basically, I'm just trying to evaluate if it's worth it for me. 

Thanks!
